author: Judith Cutrona
title: Ve√Øns de Mandri destaquen l'esperit \"c√≠vic\" del botellot
text:
Ve√Øns de Mandri destaquen l‚Äôesperit "c√≠vic" del botellot
Restauradors asseguren que van complir les normes acordades amb l‚ÄôAjuntament per evitar sancions en l‚Äôacte que va congregar 2.000 persones el vespre de Nadal.
El que va comen√ßar com una convocat√≤ria improvisada ja s‚Äôha convertit en una tradici√≥. "¬°Fins i tot en un mite!", destaca un ve√≠ del carrer Mandri de Barcelona en declaracions a EL PERI√ìDICO, que enguany no es va voler perdre el macrobotellot que va congregar 2.000 persones en aquest eix del districte de Sarri√†-Sant Gervasi la tarda de Nadal. Malgrat la multitud concentrada entre la ronda General Mitre i el carrer de Ma√≥, molts dels ve√Øns de Mandri es van despertar el mat√≠ de Sant Esteve satisfets amb l‚Äôesperit civilitzat que hi va haver. "Doncs em sembla genial. Tant de bo fos cada nit", explica una altra ve√Øna a qui li hauria agradat assistir-hi. En el seu quart any, sembla que la multitudin√†ria festa ja s‚Äôha fet un lloc.
Tot i que no hi havia convocat√≤ria oficial, els residents d‚Äôaquesta zona sabien des de fa dies quin era el pla de la tarda del 25 de desembre. Reunir-se al carrer Mandri, on es concentren els bars. Almenys tres dels establiments van tancar per aprofitar per descansar, per√≤ la resta estaven oberts. I molt preparats. Els restauradors van arribar a un acord amb el districte de Sarri√†-Sant Gervasi per evitar les sancions de m√©s de 4.000 euros que van ser imposades l‚Äôany passat. Tenien les normes clares: tancar les terrasses a les cinc de la tarda, no sobrepassar l‚Äôaforament del local i assegurar-se que cap dels clients sort√≠s al carrer amb begudes.
La gent va comen√ßar a reunir-s‚Äôhi cap a les sis de la tarda i a les vuit ja no hi cabia una agulla. Aleshores el carrer ja estava tallat al tr√†nsit. "La gent aprofita per sortir despr√©s dels √†pats de Nadal, venen a passar-s‚Äôho b√©, a respirar, a reunir-se", explica el Luiggi, a punt de complir 60 anys i amb ganes d‚Äôapuntar-se un any m√©s a la festa. Per ell, s‚Äôhauria de fer a m√©s carrers perqu√® no √©s una manifestaci√≥, sin√≥ "una festa superagradable" en qu√® hi ha un "comportament c√≠vic espectacular".
"A molta gent li fa r√†bia que la gent jove gaudeixi. √âs una cosa sana, s√≥n festes, no fa mal a ning√∫", afirma Serenela, que, acompanyada del Jorge, lamenten no haver-hi pogut assistir. "Com m√©s festa millor, sempre que hi hagi respecte i educaci√≥, evidentment". En la mateixa l√≠nia, a l‚ÄôAlex li sembla "un aut√®ntic √®xit" que es reunissin 2.000 persones "amb alcohol i que no hi hagi problemes". Tamb√© li sembla b√© que es faci la festa, tenint en compte que s√≥n dies en qu√® "la gent d‚Äôaquest barri no hi √©s". "La gent √©s civilitzada", remarca. El Javier, un dels joves que s‚Äôhi va acostar, destaca que no va veure "baralla en cap moment" ni enfrontaments quan la Gu√†rdia Urbana va desallotjar la gent.
"Deixen el carrer fet un f√†stic"
Hi ha altres ve√Øns a qui, m√©s que el soroll de la gent, els va preocupar com va quedar el carrer quan el van desallotjar cap a les 00.30 hores. "El deixen fet un f√†stic", lamenta una ve√Øna d‚Äôuns 70 anys. El seu dormitori dona justament al carrer, des d‚Äôon veia sorpresa la multitud de persones. Elles no li van fer perdre la son, per√≤ s√≠ que ho va fer el soroll dels camions de la neteja. "No han de destrossar-ho tot i desgraciar-ho".
Not√≠cies relacionadesA l‚ÄôAbel, que viu en un altre dels blocs del carrer, s√≠ que li va afectar el soroll de la gent. "Hi havia molt de soroll, gent beguda, pixant... A mi particularment no m‚Äôagrada", explica. En canvi, per a la Blanca l‚Äôinconvenient era com poder moure‚Äôs amb cotxe per la zona. "La Gu√†rdia Urbana no ens deixava circular a ning√∫, ni als ve√Øns. Des de les cinc de la tarda, tallat". Tot i aix√≠, veu b√© que se celebr√©s la festa. "Eren nens bons", diu.
Els assistents van adquirir les begudes als supermercats de la zona i als bars, que oferien combinats. Aquesta vegada els restauradors estaven conscienciats amb les normes, que asseguren que les van complir tot i que aix√≤ els ha fet perdre "molta facturaci√≥", lamenta la Marta, treballadora d‚Äôun dels bars. Per exemple, alguns van contractar porters per controlar que la gent no sort√≠s amb la beguda. Tot i aix√≠, la majoria dels bars del carrer tamb√© destaquen el bon comportament dels clients, malgrat la multitud.

author: VNExplorer
title: Horror buggy crash leaves Queensland woman critical as two others die in deadly start to holiday long weekend
text:
Woman critical after buggy rolloverTwo others dead on Queensland roads READ MORE: Young couple and their housemate are tragically killed in a horror single-car crash on a remote stretch of road
A woman is fighting for life following a horror buggy roll over in the central highlands of Queensland.
Emergency services were called to a buggy crash involving two people in Duargina, west of Rockhampton at around 1.35pm on Friday.
A buggy has rolled in Queensland with a woman left in a critcal condition. Picture: 7News
The woman, aged in her 40s, was treated at the Apis Creek Rd site for head and leg injuries before being flown to hospital in a critical condition.
The second person, a teenage boy, was also treated at the scene for a head injury before being taken to hospital in a stable condition.
Elsewhere in Queensland, an 18-year-old man died after his vehicle rolled off the Bruce Highway and crashed at Ambrose, about 30km from Gladstone, on Friday evening.
The driver, from Toolooa, died at the scene after the car left the road near Gentle Annie Road about 6.30pm.
Two passengers ‚Äì a 17-year-old male from Toolooa and a 19-year-old man from South Gladstone man ‚Äì suffered non-life-threatening injuries and were assessed at Gladstone Hospital.
Early on Saturday morning, a 27-year-old man from the north-west Brisbane suburb of Ashgrove died after his motorbike crashed into a pole.
Police said the rider was travelling along Waterworks Road shortly after midnight when his bike veered off the road and smashed into a pole.
He sustained critical injuries and died at the scene.

author: Iris Kwok
title: 10 things to do in Berkeley and Oakland on Earth Day
text: The first Earth Day was held on April 22, 1970, to raise public awareness of air and water pollution following a major oil spill in Santa Barbara. The day of protest , originally selected to fall between spring break and final exams so more students could partake, is often credited as the anniversary of the modern environmentalist movement. This year, groups in Berkeley will highlight various environmental issues, from plastic pollution to climate change, throughout the week. Whether you‚Äôre looking to learn more about native birds or bees, wanting to pick up trash at the Berkeley Marina or thinking of marching in a climate rally on Sproul Plaza, there‚Äôs something for most people. üß§ Put on your closed-toe shoes and join the city of Berkeley‚Äôs Earth Day Shoreline Cleanup . Some supplies will be available, but you‚Äôre encouraged to bring your own bucket or reusable bag, reusable gloves, trash grabbers and reusable water bottles if you have them. Volunteers will be asked to fill out a waiver. Saturday, April 20, 9-11 a.m. Shorebird Park Nature Center. FREE üå± Green The Church and the Center for Food, Faith and Justice are co-presenting an event titled ‚ÄúGrowing Healthy Communities from The Soil to The Soul.‚Äù The event, described by its organizers as a day of learning and connecting, will include a worship service, music, panel on food sovereignty and global food resilience, a green sermon and more. Speakers include Rev. Dr. Ambrose Carroll, Pastor Michael Smith of the McGee Avenue Baptist Church, gospel artist Ashling Cole, and keynote speaker Rev. Dr. Dante Quick from the First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens. Saturday, April 20, 9 a.m.-12 p.m. McGee Avenue Baptist Church. FREE ( RSVP ) üåé The second annual Berkeley Unified School District Climate Fair showcases middle school projects that explore the themes of climate change science, solutions and climate justice. The fair is a chance for students to present their takeaways from the school district‚Äôs Climate Literacy program in a non-competitive environment. There will also be hands-on activities, bike and sewing repair stations, food and prizes. Saturday, April 20, 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Longfellow Middle School (cafeteria). FREE üé§ People‚Äôs Park activists are holding an Earth Day event titled ‚ÄúPeople‚Äôs Park and Green Space in Berkeley.‚Äù The event will feature a panel by longtime park activists Maxima Ventura and Carol Denney, UC Suitcase Clinic member Sofia Alcocer and Telegraph for People activist Lindsey Damashek. Saturday, April 20, 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m. Berkeley Public Library, Central Library (Community Meeting Room). üêù Learn about native bees and insects, hear from Cafe Ohlone co-founders Vincent Medina and Louis Trevino about Ohlone land stewardship practices, or try watercolor painting at the Lawrence Hall of Science‚Äôs outdoor nature lab during its Earth Day Celebration. See the museum‚Äôs website for the event schedule; the event is included with the cost of admission. Saturday, April 20. 11 a.m.-2:25 p.m. üåº Fourth Street will be teeming with family-friendly ‚ÄúEarth-tivities‚Äù including flower pot painting, succulent and wildflower painting, face painting and pollinator necklace decoration. Berkeley High School Jazz, The 3 Elements and Smith Dobson Trio will provide live music. Saturday, April 20, 2024. 12-4 p.m. Fourth and Delaware Streets. FREE üîå Thinking of transitioning your home away from gas to electric for healthier indoor air and to reduce your carbon footprint? The Alameda chapter of the Citizens‚Äô Climate Lobby is hosting a home electrification fair , during which you‚Äôll be able to chat with home electrification specialists, learn about the rebates and tax credits that are now available, and hear from experts about the state of the electrification movement. Saturday, April 20, 2-5 p.m. David Brower Center. FREE üé• The Wild and Scenic Film Festival, an on-tour program highlighting the best environmental films that came out this year, is coming to Berkeley. The film festival‚Äôs selections include films that inspire environmental activism or showcase the earth‚Äôs beauty. Proceeds go toward the Citizens‚Äô Climate Lobby. Saturday, April 20, 7-9:30 p.m. David Brower Center. $20-$25 ( https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-wild-and-scenic-film-festival-on-tour-tickets-824446831667) üì£ Some members of Cal‚Äôs student government, the ASUC, are organizing a climate strike at Sproul Plaza. The event, according to the organizers, celebrates the progress of Berkeley‚Äôs environmental community and looks toward ‚Äúall the work that is still yet to be done.‚Äù Expect an art build, band, speakers, tabling from environmental groups and a march. Monday, April 22, 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Savio Steps, UC Berkeley. üö£ The family-friendly Berkeley Bay Festival , hosted by the city of Berkeley, will feature live music, interactive circus arts and exhibits from more than 30 environmental and wildlife conservation organizations from around the Bay Area. Don‚Äôt miss the free boat rides. Featured food vendors include Royal Egyptian, Brown Cap Organic Soft Serve (read our stories ) and many more. Saturday, April 27, 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Shorebird Park. FREE Oakland Earth Day events üå≥ The city of Oakland has an interactive map where prospective volunteers can explore events taking place across Oakland. The city‚Äôs Earth Day activities run the gamut from trash cleanups and graffiti removal to habitat restoration, painting and trail improvement. The map features events put on by the city itself as well as some hosted by local organizations. Prospective volunteers can pre-register for city-run events by filling out a volunteer form. Some sites receive more volunteers than others so if you plan to attend with a large party, the city advises you to contact the event coordinator beforehand. If you can‚Äôt make it out to an event on April 20th, the city has put together a list of Earth Day-inspired activities and resources that you can get inspiration from throughout the year. Saturday, April 20, all day. Various locations in Oakland. FREE (RSVP ) üß§ The East Bay Regional Park District is holding cleanup and restoration events at Martin Luther King Jr. Regional Shoreline, Hayward Regional Shoreline, Coyote Hills Regional Park, Point Pinole Regional Shoreline, Redwood Regional Park, Wildcat Canyon Regional Park, Don Castro Regional Recreation Area, Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach and Big Break Regional Shoreline. Saturday, April 20, 9 a.m.-12 p.m. Various locations. ( https://ebrpd.samaritan.com/custom/501/opp_details/9282) üõ∂ If you like water sports and are looking for a new way to participate in this year‚Äôs Earth Day, I Heart Oakland Alameda Estuary is hosting a cleanup with an ‚Äúon the water‚Äù option. Participants can choose to join land crews to pick up trash along the shores of Estuary Park, Jack London Aquatic Center and other locations, or they can join water-based crews to kayak or stand-up paddleboard to get to hard-to-reach cleanup locations. Participants in the ‚Äúon the water‚Äù group can bring their own watercraft or rent discounted equipment through California Canoe & Kayak. Organizers say this is a ‚Äúlong haul‚Äù event, so participants can expect a long day of physically demanding cleaning. They recommend volunteers wear sturdy shoes that protect their feet, bring sun protective equipment and dress in layers. Clean-up supplies will be provided. Saturday, April 20, 10 a.m.-1:15 p.m. Jack London Aquatic Center, Oakland. FREE ( https://www.eventbrite.com/e/earth-day-i-heart-oakland-estuary-cleanup-walk-kayak-sup-registration-786163916437?aff=oddtdtcreator) üéæ Friends of Raimondi Park are inviting volunteers to help them clean up litter around the park‚Äôs sports fields and playground in West Oakland. No equipment is necessary and water, snacks, and coffee will be provided. Saturday, April 20, 10 a.m.-12 p.m. FREE ( https://www.eventbrite.com/e/friends-of-raimondi-park-earth-day-volunteer-cleanup-tickets-826581466417?aff=ebdssbdestsearch) üß§ Keep Oakland Beautiful, MARK‚Äôs Artisans , and Urban Compassion Project are asking Oakland community members to join them at the Lake Merritt Bandstand on April 20. Participants will be provided equipment to help pick up litter around the lake. There will also be lunch provided by C‚Äôera Una Volta. Saturday, April 20, 9 a.m-12 p.m. Lake Merritt Bandstand, Oakland. FREE https://www.eventbrite.com/e/earth-day-beautification-at-lake-merritt-tickets-863145149377?aff=ebdssbdestsearch) üíß The local watershed stewardship group Friends of Sausal Creek is looking for volunteers for its array of Earth Day activities. Restoration opportunities for people with a range of skill levels are available along the path of the creek, including events taking place at Barry Place, Dimond Park and Dimond Canyon, Montclair Railroad Trail, Beaconsfield Canyon and Wood Park. Participants should wear sun protection, layers, long pants and sturdy shoes. Check the https://sausalcreek.org/event-calendar for times and locations. Saturday, April 20. (RSVP) ü¶ã Join local community organization Redwood Heights Association to spruce up the Redwood Heights Park. Activities will include expanding their butterfly garden, creating a space for native grasses and cleaning up existing plant life. Make sure to bring gloves, a hat and your gardening equipment. Refreshments will be available for participants. Saturday, April 20, 9 a.m.-1 p.m. Redwood Heights Park, Oakland. FREE ( https://rhaoakland.org/events/earth-day) Higher Ground Neighborhood Development Corp. in partnership with Better Neighborhoods, Same Neighbors is hosting a Martin Luther King Jr. Regional Shoreline Earth Day event and barbecue. Volunteers will meet at Kingfisher Picnic Area and work to try to plant 100 trees during the event. After the planting is done, community members can enjoy a barbecue to celebrate their hard work. The event starts at 1 p.m and barbecue begins at 4 p.m. Saturday, April 20. Kingfisher Picnic Area, Oakland. FREE Spend some time learning about local organizations fighting against climate change at the Chabot Space and Science Center‚Äôs ‚ÄúEarth Day in the Bay.‚Äù The event will feature guest speakers, hands-on activities, and live performances. Sunday, April 21, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Chabot Space and Science Center. Tickets are needed , children under 2 are free. "*" indicates required fields

author: Mart√≠n Chi
title: D√≠a Nacional de Protecci√≥n Civil: Conmemoran los terremotos de CDMX en Playa del Carmen - PorEsto
text: NEWSLETTER POR ESTO! Suscr√≠bete y recibe la informaci√≥n m√°s relevante Volver √öLTIMA HORA Internacional Fiscal√≠a de Estados Unidos solicita cadena perpetua para Genaro Garc√≠a Luna Volver Por [ Mart√≠n Chi ](/autor/martin-chi.html) 19 de sept. de 2024 1 min Escrito por [ Mart√≠n Chi ](/autor/martin-chi.html) En la Explanada 28 de Julio en Playa del Carmen se realiz√≥ desde muy temprano el protocolo conmemorativo Al D√≠a Nacional de Protecci√≥n Civil que se conmemora cada 19 de septiembre luego de los terremotos suscitados en Ciudad de M√©xico los a√±os 1985 y 2017. Noticia destacada Posterior a realizar honores a la bandera, se encendieron las sirenas de las unidades de socorro de diferentes dependencias en memoria de los ca√≠dos por los movimientos tel√∫ricos, adem√°s por todos los h√©roes que participaron en diferentes rescates en los momentos de esos desastres que siempre se recordar√°n, sostuvo el secretario de Protecci√≥n Civil Jorge V√°zquez Oropeza. Posteriormente alrededor del mediod√≠a se realiz√≥ el tradicional simulacro nacional que se realiza a las 11 horas en todo el pa√≠s para concientizar acerca de la prevenci√≥n y tener una pr√°ctica ante cualquier contingencia como un incendio, hurac√°n o terremoto. Noticia destacada En este ejercicio todo el personal del palacio municipal de la colonia Centro evacu√≥ el edificio para colocarse de manera segura en la Explanada 28 de Julio. Algunos de ellos compartieron sus puntos de vista con relaci√≥n a los protocolos preventivos para reducir los desastres durante una emergencia. NEWSLETTER POR ESTO! Suscr√≠bete y recibe la informaci√≥n m√°s relevante Suscr√≠bete a: Temas relacionados 01

author: admin
title: We are not alone - World and Mission - Breaking Latest News
text: ‚ÄúThis Good Friday it is illuminated by the faith that we are not alone, and the strength of the Lord pushes us to constant commitment for the good of the people.‚Äù Here is the message from Father Davide Sciocco from Guinea-Bissau, a country where the population still experiences much suffering, but where Lent and Easter are experienced with great participation and intensity Dearest friends, Easter is approaching, the most important celebration for us Christians, which unites the mystery of suffering and death with that of faith and the joy of resurrection. In this climate I reach you with some news from Guinea-Bissau, which lives in the uncertainty of the political situation, given that we are without Parliament and without any date for the elections, and therefore everything is precarious. But this Good Friday it is illuminated by the faith that we are not alone, and the strength of the Lord pushes us to constant commitment for the good of the people The first piece of good news is the return of our bishop after another three months of treatment in Italy. He is better now and in recent weeks he visited Casa Bambaran, which we have supported for years, on the occasion of the feast of Saint Joseph. THE Casa Bambaran deserves all our help, because not only welcomes 30 children with disabilities, orphans or with serious family problems, but it also has an inclusive school where children from the neighborhood study together with children with disabilities who also come from other parts of the city. It is in fact the first school in the country with this special attention and with support teachers, an absolute novelty here in Guinea-Bissau. See also Syrian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Expatriates Issues Statement Condemning Israeli Missile Attack_United Nations_International Law_Region Me too‚ÄôBor pediatric hospital offers a valuable service and continues in its relaunch phase. To this end, we will send some young doctors to Senegal to do specialization courses in paediatrics and surgery, so as to provide a quality service to the people most in need. To allow health care for children from poor families, for many years a non-profit organization in Rho (‚ÄúProgetto Anna‚Äù) has supported a special fund for their care. There are many needs, and so we want to broaden the pool of benefactors for this great need: anyone who would like to support this Fund to give hope and life to the poorest sick children can contact me. Here too we try to do our part. There Lent, in particular here it is lived in a very intense way, with moments of prayer, fasting and charity towards those most in need. This year all Christians were invited to offer the equivalent of their meal to the Caritas nutritional recovery centers scattered in various parts of the country (including the one dedicated to our Federica Banfi in Contuboel). Also very participatory Lenten catecheses for young peoplewho are always very numerous and full of enthusiasm. I thank you for your closeness in friendship, prayer and solidarity which allows me to support many realities of evangelization and development. I wish you an Easter triduum of love and peace. AND happy Easter to each of you and your families.

author: Reda√ß√£o
title: RS tem previs√£o de mais chuvas fortes nos pr√≥ximos dias
text:
10/05/2024 - 7:14
Instabilidade chega ao estado nesta sexta e permanece durante o final de semana, principalmente no centro-leste e no nordeste ga√∫chos, o que inclui a regi√£o metropolitana de Porto Alegre, j√° muito afetada pela enchente.Em meio √† maior enchente da sua hist√≥ria, o Rio Grande do Sul deve ser atingido por mais chuva a partir desta sexta-feira (10/05) e durante o final de semana, de acordo com o Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia (Inmet). O √≥rg√£o prev√™ que a instabilidade ocorra com mais for√ßa no centro-leste e no leste do estado, incluindo a regi√£o metropolitana de Porto Alegre.
Nessa √°rea, fortemente atingida pela enchente, o acumulado de chuva pode chegar a 330 mil√≠metros nos pr√≥ximos tr√™s dias, o que levou o Inmet a emitir uma nota t√©cnica para riscos geol√≥gicos, devido a poss√≠veis deslizamentos de terra e desabamentos, e tamb√©m geol√≥gicos, por meio de alagamentos e extravasamento de rios e canais.
Com novos temporais, √°reas j√° atingidas pela enchente podem sofrer inunda√ß√µes mais intensas. A regi√£o metropolitana concentra algumas das principais bacias de capta√ß√£o de rios que correm do interior ‚Äì das regi√µes dos vales, por exemplo, onde ficam os rios Ca√≠, Taquari e Sinos ‚Äì e des√°guam no Gua√≠ba, em Porto Alegre e em outras cidades pr√≥ximas.
Com o sol e o tempo seco dos √∫ltimos dias, o n√≠vel desses rios seguiu caindo, mas a volta das chuvas pode faz√™-los subir novamente, al√©m da manuten√ß√£o do n√≠vel elevado de √°gua.
Os alertas do Inmet t√™m diferentes n√≠veis para diferentes regi√µes. O mais alto, de ‚Äúperigo‚Äù, √© para a metade norte do Estado, incluindo cidades como Porto Alegre, Canoas, S√£o Leopoldo, Novo Hamburgo, Santa Maria, Passo Fundo e Caxias do Sul.
Nas regi√µes desses munic√≠pios, as chuvas podem passar dos 100 mil√≠metros por dia. A previs√£o tamb√©m aponta ventos fortes que podem chegar a at√© 100 km/h. As demais √°reas do estado est√£o em alerta de ‚Äúperigo potencial‚Äù, com chuvas de at√© 50 mil√≠metros por dia e ventos de at√© 60 km/h.
Depois disso, est√° prevista a chegada do frio. Uma massa de ar frio e seco tende a causar queda nas temperaturas em todo o estado.
Vento prejudica
At√© o momento, o estado contabiliza mais de 100 mortos e mais de 130 desaparecidos devido √† enchente que come√ßou no final de abril e segue neste come√ßo de maio. Quase 400 mil pessoas tiveram de deixar suas casas, com em torno de 70 mil delas em abrigos e 330 mil desalojadas, que est√£o em casas de familiares ou amigos.
Os modelos projetados pelo Inmet tamb√©m apontam altera√ß√£o na dire√ß√£o do vento na Lagoa dos Patos, que √© para onde escoa a √°gua do Gua√≠ba e que depois des√°gua no mar por meio de uma estreita passagem j√° no sul do estado, entre os munic√≠pios de Rio Grande e S√£o Jos√© do Norte.
Devido ao vento que pode dificultar o escoamento, cidades como Rio Grande e Pelotas seguem em alerta para inunda√ß√µes graduais, j√° que o excesso de √°gua escoa em dire√ß√£o √† regi√£o.
O rio Uruguai e seus afluentes, localizados pr√≥ximos √† fronteira oeste do Rio Grande do Sul, tamb√©m t√™m previs√£o de continuar subindo nos pr√≥ximos dias.
Chuva e emerg√™ncia tamb√©m no Maranh√£o
No outro extremo do Brasil, no estado do Maranh√£o, pelo menos 30 munic√≠pios j√° decretaram situa√ß√£o de emerg√™ncia devido √†s chuvas que atingem o estado desde abril, de acordo com informa√ß√µes confirmadas pela Defesa Civil.
Mais de mil fam√≠lias est√£o desabrigadas, e quase 3 mil pessoas, desalojadas. At√© o momento, foi registrada uma morte.
A Defesa Civil trabalha para retirar moradores de √°reas de risco, enquanto o governo do Maranh√£o tem fornecido alimenta√ß√£o aos atingidos pelas cheias por meio da rede de restaurantes populares.
gb/bl (ots)

author: PA News Agency
title: Woman believed to be held hostage in Gaza declared dead | News and Star
text: A hard-hit Israeli kibbutz has announced the death of Judih Weinstein ‚Äî an American-Canadian-Israeli woman who had been thought to be held hostage in Gaza. The news came six days after Ms Weinstein‚Äôs husband, Gad Haggai, was also declared dead. Ms Weinstein, 70, and Mr Haggai, 73, were taking an early morning walk near their home in Kibbutz Nir Oz on the morning of October 7 when Hamas militants burst across the border into Israel, killing about 1,200 people and kidnapping 240 others. In the early hours of the morning, Ms Weinstein was able to call emergency services and let them know that both she and her husband had been shot and send a message to her family. Ms Weinstein and her husband had been thought to be among the hostages still held in captivity in Gaza. But six days ago, the kibbutz announced that Mr Haggai was killed on October 7 and his body was taken to Gaza. On Thursday, the kibbutz said it had learned that Ms Weinstein was also killed on October 7 and her body is also being held in Gaza. It was not immediately clear how Israeli authorities determined their deaths. The couple are survived by two sons and two daughters and seven grandchildren, the kibbutz said. US President Joe Biden said he was ‚Äúdevastated‚Äù to learn of Ms Weinstein‚Äôs death, especially after hearing about the couple during a meeting with their daughter. The families ‚Äúhave been living through hell for weeks. No family should have to endure such an ordeal‚Äù, he said in a statement. Ms Weinstein was born in New York and was an active member of Kibbutz Nir Oz, a small community near the Gaza border where she taught English to children with special needs. The kibbutz said she also taught meditation techniques to children and teenagers who suffered from anxiety as a result of rocket fire from Gaza. Mr Haggai was a retired chef and jazz musician. ‚ÄúJudy dedicated her life to serving others, spending years teaching English and using her passions for poetry, puppeteering, and mindfulness to empower children of all backgrounds,‚Äù her family said in a statement. In a YouTube video made during a brief round of fighting between Israel and the Islamic Jihad militant group last May, Ms Weinstein read a series of poems and expressed hope for better days ahead. ‚ÄúI truly hope that the next time I‚Äôm recording some Haiku it won‚Äôt be under duress, under rocket fire, under conditions where people are at war,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMay we all be granted the right to our basic rights of home, food, shelter and peaceful days. Here‚Äôs hoping.‚Äù Al Haggai, one of the couple‚Äôs sons, told Israel‚Äôs Channel 13 that the family had originally hoped their mother‚Äôs multiple citizenships would allow her to be released during the week-long ceasefire in late November, when 105 hostages were let go. Almost all were women and children. He said that when his mother‚Äôs name was not on any of the daily lists, he started to suspect that something had happened to her. According to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu‚Äôs office, at least 23 of the approximately 129 hostages believed to be held in Gaza have either died or been killed in captivity. Nir Oz was one of the hardest-hit Israeli communities on October 7, with roughly a quarter of its residents killed or kidnapped. The families of missing hostages have drawn widespread support and sympathy in Israel as they press the government to reach a new ceasefire deal to bring home their loved ones. Mr Netanyahu met on Thursday in Tel Aviv with some of the families, where he told them there were behind-the-scene efforts to bring the hostages home, according to a statement from his office. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt elaborate on the details, we are working to return everyone,‚Äù he said. Comments: Our rules We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. The ability to comment on our stories is a privilege, not a right, however, and that privilege may be withdrawn if it is abused or misused. Please report any comments that break our rules. [Read the rules here](/misc/comments)

author: Business Standard
title: Boeing workers strike after 96% vote for walkout in test for new CEO | World News - Business Standard
text:
Boeing's US West Coast factory workers will walk off the job after 96% voted on Thursday in favor of a strike, halting production of the planemaker's strongest-selling jet as it wrestles with chronic output delays and mounting debt.
The workers' first strike since 2008 will start at midnight Pacific time (0700 GMT) as Friday begins, just weeks after new CEO Kelly Ortberg was brought on in August to restore faith in the planemaker after a door panel blew off a near-new 737 MAX jet in mid-air in January.
 Click here to connect with us on WhatsApp Roughly 30,000 workers who produce Boeing's 737 MAX and other jets in the Seattle and Portland areas voted on their first full contract in 16 years.
 International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM) members voted 96% in favor of striking and 94.6% to reject the agreement. "This is about respect, this is about addressing the past, and this is about fighting for our future," said Jon Holden, who headed the negotiations for IAM, Boeing's largest union, before announcing the vote result.
 "We strike at midnight," he said, as members in the union hall cheered and chanted: "Strike! Strike! Strike!" Boeing did not respond immediately to a request for comment.
 More From This Section US, British leaders discuss Ukraine's push to ease weapons restrictions Rajapaksa heir running for prez even after Lankans' ousted powerful clan Pope concludes Asia trip, reiterates interfaith tolerance to heal world Boeing machinists vote to strike after rejecting 25% pay raise over 4 years Unauthorised migration into EU countries declines despite heated politics The deal included a general wage increase of 25%, a $3,000 signing bonus and a pledge to build Boeing's next commercial jet in the Seattle area, provided the program was launched within the four years of the contract.
 Although IAM leadership recommended last Sunday that its members accept the contract, many workers had responded angrily, arguing for the originally demanded 40% pay rise and lamenting the loss of an annual bonus.
 "We're going to get back to the table as quickly as we can," Holden told reporters, without saying how long he thought the strike would last or when talks would resume. "This is something that we take one day at a time, one week at a time.¬ù Workers have been protesting all week in Boeing factories in the Seattle area that assemble Boeing's MAX, 777 and 767 jets.
 Boeing shares closed up 0.9% on Thursday before the vote results were announced but are down 36% this year on concerns over safety, production and a $60 billion debt burden.
 The duration of the walkout is not clear. A long strike would weigh not only on Boeing's financials, but on airlines that depend on the planemakers jets and suppliers who manufacture parts and components for its aircraft. According to a pre-vote note from TD Cowen, a 50-day strike could cost Boeing an estimated $3 billion to $3.5 billion of cash flow.
 The Boeing workers' last strike in 2008 shuttered plants for 52 days and hit revenue by an estimated $100 million per day. S&P Global Ratings said that an extended strike could delay the planemaker's recovery and hurt its overall rating. Both S&P and Moody's rate Boeing one notch above junk status.
 The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
